course.subject: ECON
course.name: Law and Economics
course.description: The economic approach to law; externalities, transaction costs, and the "Coase Theorem"; the problem of the commons; the social cost of crime and law enforcement; case studies.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 3014 OR ECON 3133) AND (MATH 1003 OR MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1023)

reviews.author: HH
reviews.comment_content:
This course provides an introduction to the economic analysis of law. Considering the law as rules that govern incentives of economic agents, we study how economic analysis could be applied to broad topics including torts (e.g., product liability and medical malpractice), property, contracts, legal procedure, crime and competition law.

As interesting as this course seemed, I'd have to say I was disappointed. They have a lot of potential to make this course really interesting. Mainly focused on the areas of torts. contract and criminal law - mainly contract and torts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof mainly reads lecture notes off the board. Wanted to go to class to get more clarity from the lecture notes but didn't didn't find that. She is a nice though.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework Assignments 30%
Midterm Exam 30%
Final Exam 40%

Homework assignments were pretty straightforward. Nothing too difficult. There were 3 of them.

Midterm exam was largely based on the tutorials. If you had prepared the tutorial materials well, midterm would have been relaxed for you.

Were allowed 2 double sided cheat sheets for the final exam, and again questions weren't too tricky.

If you prepare properly, you should not have to worry.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy workload at all. Just one midterm and final. And evenly spaced 3 problem sets.

reviews.author: 醉愛傑少
reviews.comment_content:
The course provides an introduction to the economic analysis of law. Considering the law as rules that govern incentives of economic agents, we study how economic analysis could be applied to broad topics including torts, property, contracts, legal procedure, and crime. [official description]

In short, we study how we should structure law in different scenarios with different aims (eg. In order to achieve greater efficiency, should we structure law to encourage trade or should we structure law to assign properties to those who value them the most?) We also study how people react to different legal system and the effects of liability rule/negligence rule on precaution.
reviews.comment_teaching: Yasutora's class is interesting and meaningful. He tried to make the boring LAW content fun by adding in examples
reviews.comment_grading:
[ECON 4670] If you need to fulfill the 4670 requirements, it is strongly recommended to fulfill it in this class.

There is one midterm exam (35%) and one final exam (44%). You can bring a one-page cheatsheet to both exams. There are 3 assignments (3x7% each) which are rather easy. Got A- for JUST above mean in MT and above mean 0.5SD in Final.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is minimal for a 4 credit course. Assignments are easy which required less than 2 hours each (working with your friends makes it more joyful and fruitful)
